triples.name: Extinction event
triples.relevance: The paper discusses five past mass extinction events and argues for a sixth mass extinction currently underway.

triples.name: Biodiversity
triples.relevance: The paper examines the loss of biodiversity as evidence for the sixth mass extinction.

triples.name: IUCN Red List
triples.relevance: The paper critiques the IUCN Red List for being heavily biased and underestimating extinction rates of invertebrates.

triples.name: Background extinction rate
triples.relevance: The paper compares current extinction rates to background extinction rates to demonstrate that current rates vastly exceed natural rates.

triples.name: Mollusca
triples.relevance: The paper uses molluscs as the primary example to extrapolate extinction rates across all invertebrates.

triples.name: Marine ecosystem
triples.relevance: The paper examines marine biota extinction rates and finds that marine species face threats but not the same crisis level as non-marine biota.

triples.name: Natural history
triples.relevance: The paper advocates for reviving the study of natural history as essential to documenting species before extinction.

triples.name: Taxonomy (biology)
triples.relevance: The paper emphasizes the importance of taxonomy in identifying and documenting species before they disappear.

triples.name: Invertebrate
triples.relevance: The paper focuses on invertebrates as the most understudied and severely underrepresented group in extinction assessments.

triples.name: Insular biogeography
triples.relevance: The paper discusses how island species suffer far greater extinction rates than continental species.
